content:
I see the issue now. Let's focus on what we can do with our current inventory:

```python
# First check our inventory
inventory = inspect_inventory()
print(f"Current inventory: {inventory}")

# We have:
# - 1 burner inserter
# - 1 stone furnace
# - 70 coal
# - 5 stone
# - 1 iron plate
# - 39 transport belts

# Let's place the burner inserter next to our existing furnace
furnace_pos = Position(x=2, y=2)
move_to(furnace_pos)

# Place inserter on the left side of the furnace
inserter_pos = Position(x=1, y=2)
move_to(inserter_pos)
inserter = place_entity(Prototype.BurnerInserter, Direction.RIGHT, inserter_pos)
print(f"Placed inserter at {inserter.position}")

# Add fuel to both furnace and inserter to keep them running
print("Adding fuel to machines...")
insert_item(Prototype.Coal, inserter, quantity=5)
insert_item(Prototype.Coal, furnace, quantity=5)

# Place transport belt to feed items to the inserter
belt_pos = Position(x=0, y=2)
move_to(belt_pos)
belt = place_entity(Prototype.TransportBelt, Direction.RIGHT, belt_pos)
print(f"Placed transport belt at {belt.position}")

# Check our setup
print("Checking final setup...")
print(f"Entities on map: {get_entities()}")
print(f"Final inventory: {inspect_inventory()}")
```

This setup will create:
1. A transport belt feeding into
2. A burner inserter that will feed into
3. Our existing furnace

This gives us the basic infrastructure for automation, though we'll need more iron ore to make it fully operational.
